1F9B5C16CD484D109E893D494E846BAD.description: Draw on the experience of local musicians and community members (e.g., community performances, collaborative workshops, adult musicians, guest artists from diverse cultures) to examine their work and careers and to improve own practice.

28D900FD499F4EC3A79C19B1376A275F.description: Recognize and analyse how music is used in everyday life (e.g., video games, films, social media, apps).

482D5F3FC8004193A86CAF1EFCB26222.description: Conduct an inquiry into how change (e.g., personal, social, technology) influences musical works.

4BAB2AAD6CE04CA385F86625D617028B.description: Examine how music and musicians influence and respond to social, political and cultural issues (e.g., representing gender and sexual diversity, concern for environmental sustainability or human rights, world music activists).

D707C6F7344B499BA3B4C1BFE8ABC718.description: Investigate why influential musicians (e.g., current, historical, community) and music educators (e.g., Kodaly, John-Baptiste Arcand, Orff, Buffy Sainte-Marie, Jose Antonio Abreu) and their work are/were influential.

76FD4CE5EBFC4533B319C733162F85C1.description: Identify, listen to and discuss the work of musicians who have made an impact on music.

A778CEA0AD0849C48F18E0A7EE918053.description: Explore the lives and work of local, Canadian and international musicians.

4F7E1F6DF2DE4F5D9970D99CB250E8DF.description: Discuss entrepreneurship and personal qualities required for pursuing a career in music.

01DD44B050B54D5FBCD178D9652DA360.description: Research supports for musicians such as unions, professional associations, agents, Elders and Knowledge Keepers, provincial and federal grants (e.g., funding for creation, touring and recording).

FCA7C7E5E8A94C11B8800C711A86D323.description: Examine legalities (e.g., copyrighting, trademarking, First Nations traditional laws, contracts) and ethics (e.g., illegal downloading, sampling, cultural protocols, compensation from streaming services) related to creating and producing music.

2BCC8FBE947849AD840C3B3C32CC2C38.description: Examine ways that First Nations musicians learn to sing and play in powwow drum groups.

F316495D7B3A46D48F6E527C69A82338.description: Conduct an inquiry into career opportunities in music and investigate opportunities (e.g., career avenues in specific disciplines, scholarships, entrepreneurial skills required, performance contract fees, licensing and financial compensation for digital distribution of recordings) for continuing the study of music.

53C287FB2B1E4D43B7250FB357CC995B.description: Explore opportunities and benefits for continuing lifelong engagement in music (e.g., community choirs, bands, musical theatre).

A76D4AE546C14D10BBCD73F7098427D2.description: Make connections between music and other areas of study (e.g., literature, math, science, social sciences, physical education, other arts).

7FB91B42365A424BA487A35CC98EA72C.description: Examine ways that different genres/styles of music influence one’s wellbeing (e.g., mood, anxiety, sense of peace) and examine how music is used in media and infused in daily life (e.g., to influence consumers via advertising, shopping environments).

DDF8A366E9754D0AA178EAABC81A6C0B.description: Investigate relationships between music and personal wellness including mental health (e.g., music therapy) and identify and discuss associated research.

A98BB9C1673841B09EB6A4108F731A2A.description: Describe the impact and role of music in own life and identify music careers and pathways for continuing engagement in music.

4F0A28D7F61E4B92829121A802A82213.description: Examine ways in which audience responses in different musical genres affect the musician’s performance and the audience’s experience.

5746DFB5B8B24BA8ADCABF54C70F1242.description: Investigate the origins of performance and audience etiquette (e.g., clapping following jazz solos, silence between symphonic movements) in different genres of music.

BE3AA4F0B6AF4CA78F9A44DF5731D87F.description: Anticipate and prepare for how audiences might react to the music performed in relation to, for example, venue, genre, demographics or type of event.

33ABA594CAA04A0184EF82E861CD8E59.description: Respond as an audience member and perform in a manner appropriate to the genre (e.g., First Nations powwow, symphony, jazz, African or Latin percussion drum group, rock band) respecting cultural protocols and performance norms (e.g., deportment, attire, respect for local tradition, awaiting invitation to join jam session, bowing, encore).

464ED6781BB94857BCB631CC9686A3C8.description: Identify protocols for audience and performer according to norms within the genre.

519C9BDC24704A71BA2FD65D59D1CDF4.description: Explore the evolution of instruments, voice and creative technologies and their use in various world cultures and time periods.

88DB00C0516041A09865946B76B71BAC.description: Conduct an inquiry into how music from the past is recreated today, or how music of today can be reinterpreted in styles from the past.

2F8A7CC40AA248F7A10FF7F9AD4D260B.description: Investigate the influence of personal experience and place on the creation of selected music.

A4C013938FA84130A2DE8B5D771E472C.description: Investigate the influence of cultural and historical contexts on the creation of selected music.

764089086E3B4D6E9FC7B756039CBB39.description: Identify musical, cultural, aural, textual clues that indicate the music’s place and time.

A033E57B4FA34BF29EB59A6A8699DEF2.description: Identify characteristics of the different eras, genres and styles through listening to and/or performing the representative music.

F1FBAF667E0547FB908D4272C27EB3CA.description: Cultural/Historical (CH) Goal: Students will investigate the content and aesthetics of the arts within cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts, and understand the connection between the arts and the human experience.

E2D151D3FF5F4FA0A895DAA463B23AA5.description: Make personal connections to the music and provide reasons for individual preferences.

CBB589F818C54A04874EF6CB9F5201E9.description: Analyse and interpret music using evidence from the piece and/or performance including examination of the importance of musical text.

4DDBFB991EE64FCF8B9F532E2AB8BFDC.description: Explain relationships between acoustics and sound.

991F37DDBD4C4643A73FEAE75E1B413D.description: Analyse the characteristics of excellent performance through listening to and watching other performers.

ED0AD932F0D6418B90FEC605829CE17F.description: Respond critically (e.g., written, oral, arts expression) to music from various genres, styles, times, places, social groups and cultures using terminology specific to the music genre.

D519684EC57B4B5EB5053806F1F26F7A.description: Examine and classify music representing various genres, styles, time periods, places, social groups, world cultures, composers and performers.

40FDEBE402144EC496BD1AA57370FED7.description: Express initial reactions, while listening to music, and conduct further analysis based on evidence in the work.

1404FF1AE44147D3AAEA6B4AF73C2A80.description: Listen and respond to musical expressions of others, differentiating between critical analysis and personal preference.

9CE9B902B55E4200A9C9B95E1F64AA0F.description: Explain relationships between acoustics and sound, experiment with acoustics of various environments and discuss acoustic design considerations.

5F3B1220F99C4F5AAFE16AFB2E1471F6.description: Conduct an inquiry into ways technology (e.g., microphones, software, pedals) and materials (e.g., drum heads, mutes, baffles, curtains) can manipulate sound.

343607FCDBA04315AF79133CB0F3DAFB.description: Identify equipment (e.g., instruments, accessories, amplification systems, acoustical designs, technologies) that impacts sound quality.

5D873237845544F3A70B53F0909B7EAE.description: Apply methods to improve sound quality through care and maintenance of instruments and/or voices.

19BC6747B18D44C090FD483A291F76ED.description: With guidance, generate technique-related inquiry questions and set short term goals for personal improvement based on the inquiry findings.

9EAC03EAC64F429BBF7C3E3C2AB4F820.description: Respond to qualities of musical elements such as tone, pitch, dynamics and rhythm as well as style, intonation and phrasing within own musical expressions.

59B415A52EE146AF919A7F41AE062D5A.description: Examine own musical expressions, using teacher feedback and self-assessment, in order to improve.

E7AB8797EC414A40B8CBF504084E49A0.description: Listen and respond critically to own musical expressions and, with guidance, set short term goals for musical growth.

CB8454F2E890458D894F694254272DE1.description: Explore the regional and/or stylistic differences in Métis music (e.g., kitchen parties, reels, spoons, crooked tunes, jigging and other dances).

B3F7942F5A534FA48C710F063BA390C9.description: Examine how Métis music and musicians in Saskatchewan influence and respond to social, political and cultural issues.

4EEFF9B32CB542419924CDD8306D0192.description: Describe various purposes for Métis music (e.g., celebration, storytelling, dance accompaniment, competition).

0DEFB010773B419599142B8628746B7D.description: Recognize how the work of contemporary Métis musicians is influenced by traditional music.

E1559373CE054084B9FB124605240EFE.description: Discuss ways of knowing and learning (e.g., songs passed down, songs composed) that are applied to learning traditional and contemporary Métis music.

D17F91827F1A4724A216A776D6561D7A.description: Engage with Métis musicians to introduce characteristics of traditional Métis music.

88FB21E2482B4612A9CF167430E2D84E.description: Investigate and respond to the music of Saskatchewan Métis peoples.

F31761400DC3478BBB1F48F9E40EF2BE.description: Explore the differences in music and protocols among First Nations.

3F005CAABE2A4C968C0A1D82039DA9B6.description: Describe protocols for singing and drumming at powwows including different gender roles.

0C367821ED6B4B1492E34F3723EC734D.description: Identify how First Nations music is used for different purposes (e.g., public songs, social songs, ceremonial songs).

35274764ABDA4738B769A162A191C64F.description: Examine how music and musicians, including current Saskatchewan musicians, influence and respond to social, political and cultural issues (e.g., treaty education outcome SI10 - examine the spirit and intent of Treaties and investigate [within the context of music] the extent to which they have been fulfilled).

696E36F45AA04C68B0E523175458F545.description: Recognize how the work of contemporary musicians is influenced by traditional First Nations music.

3121DA7BF7C8403CBA42AE135B2F2C6B.description: Discuss ways of knowing and learning (e.g., songs passed down/gifted, songs composed) that are applied to learning First Nations traditional and contemporary music.

24B2C17072B2467D972C373AAD6D0FBF.description: Engage with First Nations Elders, Knowledge Keepers and/or musicians to introduce music associated with round dance and various powwow dances (e.g., fancy dance, men’s and women’s traditional, jingle dress).

F12D92C368C44465850F1A0963724265.description: Investigate and respond to powwow and other social music of Saskatchewan First Nations peoples.

1A862EB587A24377ADA406C30A3E3FC6.description: Critical/Responsive (CR) Goal: Students will respond to artistic expressions of Saskatchewan, Canadian, and International artists using critical thinking, research, creativity, and collaborative inquiry.

B99C801DD1804CA79DC8611C81F67DE1.description: Develop language appropriate to the musical genre and style to talk about improvisation.

FD8A87FF71C34D67993A77FD19A96647.description: Imitate or transcribe musical ideas (e.g., listen and play).

69FACA39759841C58EA8085B9E25A20B.description: Demonstrate knowledge of selected musical concepts (e.g., elements of music, composition principles) through improvisation

470A04BF5C604A73B805076628A1F2FB.description: Demonstrate growth in the presentation and construction of improvisation.

B2EDABEB4FB74B64BD7A393F3F9EAB93.description: Examine the work of musicians engaged in improvisation.

42E4744C6991417890A0D2329896A105.description: Explore how improvisation is used within a variety of genres.

BD070FD8F351407780A8FEE16B7028F7.description: Improvise around a given structure and in free form.

EA41D9FD29A548CB853010B3C8E7FAE2.description: Improvise on an instrument or with voice or other creative technology, exploring and experimenting with music theory, cultural or performance practice.

059A4B92E401427A83751B76AB7A9ADE.description: Examine music composition processes within diverse genres and cultural contexts (e.g., partner with local musicians from various genres and cultures through artists in schools projects).

01228C2AA3DD45B38074B1945E77B465.description: Discuss the difference between ‘drawing inspiration from music’ versus ‘engaging in cultural appropriation or copyright infringement’ when composing.

6CAF70477D63427C93E72DE356B19647.description: Apply aural skills to making musical decisions for sound compositions.

2A4D1A98248A4E73B700ECB7A00853EB.description: Demonstrate, through rehearsal, an ability to reflect on, refine and revise solo and ensemble compositions.

829E2FAF6FDD41CFA15FAABFC2CB9FD6.description: Understand and experiment with the elements of music (i.e., melody, harmony, rhythm, dynamics, form, tone, texture) and principles of composition (e.g., repetition and variation, tension and resolution, balance and unity).

72CDA24DCB874CE491021860FABD7188.description: Express musical ideas, through composition individually and/or in ensemble settings, that can be recreated by others.

E098C7B3B0334E3CA13E3ED5BB1A41C7.description: Compose to express musical ideas experimenting with the elements of music and principles of composition, respecting cultural contexts.

2EDA32888C2D40DDAEE9E92D6B1D8E09.description: Represent musical ideas using non-standard notation (e.g., abstract symbols and text, timebased pictographs, rap and hip hop flow diagrams with lyrics under beat numbers, braille, colour coded) and/or culture specific forms and models (e.g., unwritten, memorized with fixed and/or variable elements).

7FDD16320B674BBB8C6127F780E22815.description: Represent musical ideas using standard notation (i.e., Western music notation, tablature).

6BF5B67030FC4567974A0C932475A8E8.description: Investigate legal and ethical practices in music composition, performance and recording.

2BCC879568FB4FF1B05173EE30F4FD39.description: Read and interpret written musical communication.

6874D1B75C9048EEB357B7713B099D73.description: Experiment with various types of notation to communicate musical ideas (e.g., graphic/invented, tablature, standard and culture-specific forms).

12A14F9A3BC14A5AAD83B142D87C3B78.description: Demonstrate musicality (e.g., emotional expressiveness) in solo and/or ensemble performance.

00B3B6B01D6A41099BD737E4E1D5F5EE.description: Develop the ability to communicate and interact with ensemble members and/or audience.

0890AE7641E44763BC5929F02E53381A.description: Track development of instrumental or vocal techniques and develop strategies to improve.

4B09FBD0D7B340FAACDA6FFC16A2E305.description: Demonstrate knowledge of one’s own role within an ensemble.

2BCBA2D6593A4A44ACC90533FCC96F7A.description: Develop the skills and techniques required for successful ensemble performances.

41EF0CB93FBB433896033BEB28CC27AB.description: With guidance, generate technique-related inquiry questions and set short term goals for personal improvement based on the inquiry findings.

7C4A70CC90A64C8BAC373B2908FBB57D.description: Develop vocabulary appropriate to genre or musical context.

083094B516434A3DBB7E0F7291C99D24.description: Demonstrate instrumental or vocal technique and knowledge of the elements of music.

1B9F77A398414DB99AAAE190ACB5283C.description: Investigate techniques (i.e., instrumental, vocal or creative technologies) and the elements of music for solo and/or ensemble performances.

C47270A16C044B24ADF68CC04EED92A3.description: Creative/Productive (CP) Goal: Students will inquire, create, and communicate through dance, drama, music and visual art.
